noun.description: A rough-surfaced woolen cloth, typically of mixed flecked colors, originally produced in Scotland.

proper noun.description: A river that rises in southeastern Scotland and flows east for 97 miles (155 km) before it crosses into northeastern England and enters the North Sea. Part of its lower course forms the border between Scotland and England.

origin: Mid 19th century: originally a misreading of tweel, Scots form of twill, influenced by association with the Tweed River.
